segment.source: Receive, process, and manage input data from pointing devices, such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad, in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Receive, process, and manage input data from pointing devices, such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad, in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: Handle pointer input
segment.target: Handle pointer input

segment.source: Handle pointer input
segment.target: Handle pointer input

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Receive, process, and manage input data from pointing devices, such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad, in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: Receive, process, and manage input data from pointing devices, such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad, in Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: Important APIs
segment.target: Important APIs

segment.source: Windows.Devices.Input
segment.target: Windows.Devices.Input

segment.source: Windows.UI.Input
segment.target: Windows.UI.Input

segment.source: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input
segment.target: Windows.UI.Xaml.Input

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If you implement your own interaction support, keep in mind that users expect an intuitive experience involving direct interaction with the UI elements in your app.
segment.target: If you implement your own interaction support, keep in mind that users expect an intuitive experience involving direct interaction with the UI elements in your app.

segment.source: We recommend that you model your custom interactions on the Controls list to keep things consistent and discoverable.
segment.target: We recommend that you model your custom interactions on the Controls list to keep things consistent and discoverable.

segment.source: The platform controls provide the full Universal Windows Platform (UWP) user interaction experience, including standard interactions, animated physics effects, visual feedback, and accessibility.
segment.target: The platform controls provide the full Universal Windows Platform (UWP) user interaction experience, including standard interactions, animated physics effects, visual feedback, and accessibility.

segment.source: Create custom interactions only if there is a clear, well-defined requirement and basic interactions don't support your scenario.
segment.target: Create custom interactions only if there is a clear, well-defined requirement and basic interactions don't support your scenario.

segment.source: Pointers
segment.target: Pointers

segment.source: Many interaction experiences involve the user identifying the object they want to interact with by pointing at it using input devices such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad.
segment.target: Many interaction experiences involve the user identifying the object they want to interact with by pointing at it using input devices such as touch, mouse, pen/stylus, and touchpad.

segment.source: Because the raw Human Interface Device (HID) data provided by these input devices includes many common properties, the info is promoted into a unified input stack and exposed as consolidated, device-agnostic pointer data.
segment.target: Because the raw Human Interface Device (HID) data provided by these input devices includes many common properties, the info is promoted into a unified input stack and exposed as consolidated, device-agnostic pointer data.

segment.source: Your UWP apps can then consume this data without worrying about the input device being used.
segment.target: Your UWP apps can then consume this data without worrying about the input device being used.

segment.source: Note Device-specific info is also promoted from the raw HID data should your app require it.
segment.target: Note Device-specific info is also promoted from the raw HID data should your app require it.

segment.source: Each input point (or contact) on the input stack is represented by a Pointer object exposed through the PointerRoutedEventArgs parameter provided by various pointer events.
segment.target: Each input point (or contact) on the input stack is represented by a Pointer object exposed through the PointerRoutedEventArgs parameter provided by various pointer events.

segment.source: In the case of multi-pen or multi-touch input, each contact is treated as a unique input point.
segment.target: In the case of multi-pen or multi-touch input, each contact is treated as a unique input point.

segment.source: Pointer events
segment.target: Pointer events

segment.source: Pointer events expose basic info such as detection state (in range or in contact) and device type, and extended info such as location, pressure, and contact geometry.
segment.target: Pointer events expose basic info such as detection state (in range or in contact) and device type, and extended info such as location, pressure, and contact geometry.

segment.source: In addition, specific device properties such as which mouse button a user pressed or whether the pen eraser tip is being used are also available.
segment.target: In addition, specific device properties such as which mouse button a user pressed or whether the pen eraser tip is being used are also available.

segment.source: If your app needs to differentiate between input devices and their capabilities, see Identify input devices.
segment.target: If your app needs to differentiate between input devices and their capabilities, see Identify input devices.

segment.source: UWP apps can listen for the following pointer events:
segment.target: UWP apps can listen for the following pointer events:

segment.source: Note Call CapturePointer to constrain pointer input to a specific UI element.
segment.target: Note Call CapturePointer to constrain pointer input to a specific UI element.

segment.source: When a pointer is captured by an element, only that object receives the pointer input events, even when the pointer moves outside the bounding area of the object.
segment.target: When a pointer is captured by an element, only that object receives the pointer input events, even when the pointer moves outside the bounding area of the object.

segment.source: You typically capture the pointer within a PointerPressed event handler as IsInContact (mouse button pressed, touch or stylus in contact) must be true for CapturePointer to be successful.
segment.target: You typically capture the pointer within a PointerPressed event handler as IsInContact (mouse button pressed, touch or stylus in contact) must be true for CapturePointer to be successful.

segment.source: Event
segment.target: Event

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: [PointerCanceled](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208964)
segment.target: [PointerCanceled](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208964)

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer is canceled by the platform.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer is canceled by the platform.

segment.source: Touch pointers are canceled when a pen is detected within range of the input surface.
segment.target: Touch pointers are canceled when a pen is detected within range of the input surface.

segment.source: An active contact is not detected for more than 100 ms.
segment.target: An active contact is not detected for more than 100 ms.

segment.source: Monitor/display is changed (resolution, settings, multi-mon configuration).
segment.target: Monitor/display is changed (resolution, settings, multi-mon configuration).

segment.source: The desktop is locked or the user has logged off.
segment.target: The desktop is locked or the user has logged off.

segment.source: The number of simultaneous contacts exceeded the number supported by the device.
segment.target: The number of simultaneous contacts exceeded the number supported by the device.

segment.source: [PointerCaptureLost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208965)
segment.target: [PointerCaptureLost](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208965)

segment.source: Occurs when another UI element captures the pointer, the pointer was released, or another pointer was programmatically captured.
segment.target: Occurs when another UI element captures the pointer, the pointer was released, or another pointer was programmatically captured.

segment.source: Note There is no corresponding pointer capture event.
segment.target: Note There is no corresponding pointer capture event.

segment.source: [PointerEntered](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208968)
segment.target: [PointerEntered](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208968)

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer enters the bounding area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer enters the bounding area of an element.

segment.source: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.
segment.target: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.

segment.source: Touch requires a finger contact to fire this event, either from a direct touch down on the element or from moving into the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Touch requires a finger contact to fire this event, either from a direct touch down on the element or from moving into the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.
segment.target: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.

segment.source: Like touch, pen fires this event with a direct pen down on the element or from moving into the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Like touch, pen fires this event with a direct pen down on the element or from moving into the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that, when true, fires this event.
segment.target: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that, when true, fires this event.

segment.source: [PointerExited](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208969)
segment.target: [PointerExited](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208969)

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer leaves the bounding area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer leaves the bounding area of an element.

segment.source: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.
segment.target: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.

segment.source: Touch requires a finger contact and fires this event when the pointer moves out of the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Touch requires a finger contact and fires this event when the pointer moves out of the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.
segment.target: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.

segment.source: Like touch, pen fires this event when moving out of the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Like touch, pen fires this event when moving out of the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that fires this event when the state changes from true to false.
segment.target: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that fires this event when the state changes from true to false.

segment.source: [PointerMoved](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208970)
segment.target: [PointerMoved](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208970)

segment.source: Occurs when a pointer changes coordinates, button state, pressure, tilt, or contact geometry (for example, width and height) within the bounding area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when a pointer changes coordinates, button state, pressure, tilt, or contact geometry (for example, width and height) within the bounding area of an element.

segment.source: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.
segment.target: This can happen in slightly different ways for touch, touchpad, mouse, and pen input.

segment.source: Touch requires a finger contact and fires this event only when in contact within the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Touch requires a finger contact and fires this event only when in contact within the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.
segment.target: Mouse and touchpad both have an on-screen cursor that is always visible and fires this event even if no mouse or touchpad button is pressed.

segment.source: Like touch, pen fires this event when in contact within the bounding area of the element.
segment.target: Like touch, pen fires this event when in contact within the bounding area of the element.

segment.source: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that, when true and within the bounding area of the element, fires this event.
segment.target: However, pen also has a hover state ([IsInRange](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br227977)) that, when true and within the bounding area of the element, fires this event.

segment.source: [PointerPressed](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208971)
segment.target: [PointerPressed](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208971)

segment.source: Occurs when the pointer indicates a press action (such as a touch down, mouse button down, pen down, or touchpad button down) within the bounding area of an element.
segment.target: Occurs when the pointer indicates a press action (such as a touch down, mouse button down, pen down, or touchpad button down) within the bounding area of an element.

segment.source: [CapturePointer](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208918) must be called from the handler for this event.
segment.target: [CapturePointer](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208918) must be called from the handler for this event.

segment.source: [PointerReleased](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208972)
segment.target: [PointerReleased](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208972)

segment.source: Occurs when the pointer indicates a release action (such as a touch up, mouse button up, pen up, or touchpad button up) within the bounding area of an element or, if the pointer is captured, outside the bounding area.
segment.target: Occurs when the pointer indicates a release action (such as a touch up, mouse button up, pen up, or touchpad button up) within the bounding area of an element or, if the pointer is captured, outside the bounding area.

segment.source: [PointerWheelChanged](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208973)
segment.target: [PointerWheelChanged](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208973)

segment.source: Occurs when the mouse wheel is rotated.
segment.target: Occurs when the mouse wheel is rotated.

segment.source: Mouse input is associated with a single pointer assigned when mouse input is first detected.
segment.target: Mouse input is associated with a single pointer assigned when mouse input is first detected.

segment.source: Clicking a mouse button (left, wheel, or right) creates a secondary association between the pointer and that button through the [PointerMoved](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208970) event.
segment.target: Clicking a mouse button (left, wheel, or right) creates a secondary association between the pointer and that button through the [PointerMoved](https://msdn.microsoft.com/library/windows/apps/br208970) event.

segment.source: Example
segment.target: Example

segment.source: Here's some code examples from a basic pointer tracking app that show how to listen for and handle pointer events and get various properties for active pointers.
segment.target: Here's some code examples from a basic pointer tracking app that show how to listen for and handle pointer events and get various properties for active pointers.

segment.source: Create the UI
segment.target: Create the UI

segment.source: For this example, we use a rectangle () as the target object for pointer input.
segment.target: For this example, we use a rectangle () as the target object for pointer input.

segment.source: The color of the target changes when the pointer status changes.
segment.target: The color of the target changes when the pointer status changes.

segment.source: Details for each pointer are displayed in a floating text block that moves with the pointer.
segment.target: Details for each pointer are displayed in a floating text block that moves with the pointer.

segment.source: The pointer events themselves are displayed to the left of the rectangle (for reporting event sequence).
segment.target: The pointer events themselves are displayed to the left of the rectangle (for reporting event sequence).

segment.source: This is the Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) for this example.
segment.target: This is the Extensible Application Markup Language (XAML) for this example.

segment.source: Listen for pointer events
segment.target: Listen for pointer events

segment.source: In most cases, we recommend that you get pointer info through the PointerRoutedEventArgs of the event handler.
segment.target: In most cases, we recommend that you get pointer info through the PointerRoutedEventArgs of the event handler.

segment.source: If the event argument doesn't expose the pointer details required, you can get access to extended PointerPoint info exposed through the GetCurrentPoint and GetIntermediatePoints methods of PointerRoutedEventArgs.
segment.target: If the event argument doesn't expose the pointer details required, you can get access to extended PointerPoint info exposed through the GetCurrentPoint and GetIntermediatePoints methods of PointerRoutedEventArgs.

segment.source: For this example, we use a rectangle () as the target object for pointer input.
segment.target: For this example, we use a rectangle () as the target object for pointer input.

segment.source: The color of the target changes when the pointer status changes.
segment.target: The color of the target changes when the pointer status changes.

segment.source: The following code sets up the target object, declares global variables, and identifies the various pointer event listeners for the target.
segment.target: The following code sets up the target object, declares global variables, and identifies the various pointer event listeners for the target.

segment.source: Handle pointer events
segment.target: Handle pointer events

segment.source: Next, we use UI feedback to demonstrate basic pointer event handlers.
segment.target: Next, we use UI feedback to demonstrate basic pointer event handlers.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerPressed event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerPressed event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer array used for tracking the pointers of interest, and display the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer array used for tracking the pointers of interest, and display the pointer details.

segment.source: Note PointerPressed and PointerReleased events do not always occur in pairs.
segment.target: Note PointerPressed and PointerReleased events do not always occur in pairs.

segment.source: Your app should listen for and handle any event that might conclude a pointer down action (such as PointerExited, PointerCanceled, and PointerCaptureLost).
segment.target: Your app should listen for and handle any event that might conclude a pointer down action (such as PointerExited, PointerCanceled, and PointerCaptureLost).

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerEntered event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerEntered event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer collection, and display the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer collection, and display the pointer details.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerMoved event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerMoved event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log and update the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log and update the pointer details.

segment.source: Important Mouse input is associated with a single pointer assigned when mouse input is first detected.
segment.target: Important Mouse input is associated with a single pointer assigned when mouse input is first detected.

segment.source: Clicking a mouse button (left, wheel, or right) creates a secondary association between the pointer and that button through the PointerPressed event.
segment.target: Clicking a mouse button (left, wheel, or right) creates a secondary association between the pointer and that button through the PointerPressed event.

segment.source: The PointerReleased event is fired only when that same mouse button is released (no other button can be associated with the pointer until this event is complete).
segment.target: The PointerReleased event is fired only when that same mouse button is released (no other button can be associated with the pointer until this event is complete).

segment.source: Because of this exclusive association, other mouse button clicks are routed through the PointerMoved event.
segment.target: Because of this exclusive association, other mouse button clicks are routed through the PointerMoved event.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerWheelChanged event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerWheelChanged event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer array (if necessary), and display the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, add the pointer to the pointer array (if necessary), and display the pointer details.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerReleased event where contact with the digitizer is terminated.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerReleased event where contact with the digitizer is terminated.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer collection, and update the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer collection, and update the pointer details.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerExited event where contact with the digitizer is maintained.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerExited event where contact with the digitizer is maintained.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerCanceled event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerCanceled event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.

segment.source: This handler manages a PointerCaptureLost event.
segment.target: This handler manages a PointerCaptureLost event.

segment.source: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.
segment.target: We add the event to the event log, remove the pointer from the pointer array, and update the pointer details.

segment.source: Note PointerCaptureLost can occur instead of PointerReleased.
segment.target: Note PointerCaptureLost can occur instead of PointerReleased.

segment.source: Pointer capture can be lost for various reasons.
segment.target: Pointer capture can be lost for various reasons.

segment.source: Get pointer properties
segment.target: Get pointer properties

segment.source: As stated earlier, you must get most extended pointer info from a Windows.UI.Input.PointerPoint object obtained through the GetCurrentPoint and GetIntermediatePoints methods of PointerRoutedEventArgs.
segment.target: As stated earlier, you must get most extended pointer info from a Windows.UI.Input.PointerPoint object obtained through the GetCurrentPoint and GetIntermediatePoints methods of PointerRoutedEventArgs.

segment.source: First, we create a new TextBlock for each pointer.
segment.target: First, we create a new TextBlock for each pointer.

segment.source: Then we provide a way to update the pointer info in an existing TextBlock associated with that pointer.
segment.target: Then we provide a way to update the pointer info in an existing TextBlock associated with that pointer.

segment.source: Finally, we query various pointer properties.
segment.target: Finally, we query various pointer properties.
